headline: Government's Water Reforms Pass Final Hurdle Amid Warnings of Soaring Rate Hikes
summary: Parliament's agenda was dominated by the final passage of the Government's contentious water services legislation, which opponents claim will lead to massive household rate increases. The day also featured fiery Question Time clashes over the cost of living and tax priorities, alongside debates on new bills aimed at limiting forestry conversions and modernising transport regulations.

topicSummaries.topic: Controversial Water Reforms Pass Final Reading, Opponents Warn of Major Rate Increases
topicSummaries.content: The Government's 'Local Water Done Well' legislation passed its third and final reading, cementing the repeal of the previous Labour government's 'Three Waters' model. The new framework returns control of water assets to local councils, offering a range of service delivery models like council-controlled organisations (CCOs). Minister Casey Costello, speaking for the Government, argued the reforms maintain local ownership and provide councils with the tools for financially sustainable water services. However, the Opposition strongly condemned the move, with Labour, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori warning that the fragmented model lacks economies of scale and will force councils to impose significant rate hikes on households, with some estimates suggesting increases of over $1,700 a year in certain districts.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Casey Costello (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: Local Water Done Well will maintain local ownership, choice, and decision-making. That gives councils the best shot at identifying their most pressing problems and the right approach to solving them.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tangi Utikere (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill... confirms and cements for households all around our country and in communities that they are to bear higher prices because of this Government's 'Local Water Done Badly' form of water reform. Higher prices.

topicSummaries.topic: PM Luxon and Opposition Leader Hipkins Clash on Cost of Living and Govt Priorities
topicSummaries.content: Question Time saw Prime Minister Christopher Luxon and Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins engage in a series of heated exchanges over the Government's economic priorities amidst the cost-of-living crisis. Hipkins repeatedly challenged the Prime Minister on decisions to provide tax cuts for landlords and tobacco companies while cutting funding for emergency housing and offering teachers a pay increase below inflation. Luxon defended his government's actions, stating they were fixing a "failed legacy" in housing by moving families out of motels and that tax relief was essential for low and middle-income workers. The debate grew tense over the framing of tobacco tax revenue changes, with Winston Peters accusing Labour of repeating a "lie."

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why did his Government prioritise a $3 billion tax cut for landlords, whilst cutting funding for emergency housing and increasing the number of people who are living homeless on the streets?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, because we actually want people out of motels, and, as the member will understand, in his time of Government, homelessness went up 34 percent despite spending a billion dollars on emergency housing. We have got good management, good Ministers; they've done the work, and they've managed to get families with kids into warm, dry homes.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Limit Exotic Forestry on Farmland Passes Second Reading with Fractured Support
topicSummaries.content: A bill designed to limit the conversion of productive farmland to exotic forestry for carbon credits passed its second reading, but with shifting support. The Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading Scheme—Forestry Conversion) Amendment Bill prevents exotic forests from being registered in the ETS on high-quality land (LUC classes 1-5) and caps it on moderately versatile land. The Government argued this strikes a crucial balance between food production, rural communities, and climate goals. While Labour offered qualified support, calling it a "margin call", the Green Party withdrew its earlier backing, arguing the bill is a "dog's breakfast" that fails to address the fundamental flaws of using unlimited forestry offsets in the Emissions Trading Scheme.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Penny Simmonds (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is not anti-forestry. It is pro-balance. It is pro - rural resilience. It's part of a broader shift towards a climate response that is grounded in integrity and shaped by the voices of those who live and work on the land.

keyExchanges.speaker: Steve Abel (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: All sides being unhappy—and I mean foresters and I mean Beef + Lamb New Zealand—is an indication that the balance has not been struck right, and, in fact, the bill is something of a dog's breakfast. It is not solving the problem.

topicSummaries.topic: Major Building Consent Overhaul Unveiled, Shifting Liability from Councils
topicSummaries.content: The Government announced its plan for the biggest changes to the building consent system in two decades, focused on shifting liability for defective work away from councils. Answering questions in the House, Building and Construction Minister Chris Penk outlined a move from the current 'joint and several liability' model to a 'proportionate liability' system. Under the current rules, councils can be held responsible for the full cost of fixing defects, even if they are only minimally at fault. The Government argues this makes councils risk-averse and slows down consenting. The new model aims to make builders, architects, and engineers liable only for their share of the blame, a move the Government says will hold "cowboy builders" accountable and speed up construction.

keyExchanges.speaker: Ryan Hamilton (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Why does the system need to change?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Penk (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Councils are currently understandably hesitant to sign off building work that Kiwis desperately need. This is because they can be left carrying the can for the full cost of building defects, even when they are not responsible to that extent. Ratepayers pay twice—once through slow, inefficient consenting and again when councils cover for cowboy builders who've ridden off into the sunset, saddling the ratepayer with the bill.

topicSummaries.topic: Transport Bill to Enable Digital Driver's Licences Passes First Reading
topicSummaries.content: A wide-ranging transport bill aimed at modernising regulations passed its first reading with broad cross-party support. The Regulatory Systems (Transport) Amendment Bill is an omnibus bill that includes numerous technical updates. Its most significant public-facing measure is the creation of a legal framework to introduce optional digital driver's licences in New Zealand, allowing drivers to use a digital version on their phones. The bill also moves to digitise vehicle registration, gives the NZ Transport Agency clearer powers to close State Highways for safety reasons, and corrects several minor drafting errors in existing transport law. Associate Minister of Transport James Meager described it as a "dull but worthy" bill that builds on the work of successive governments.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon James Meager (National)
keyExchanges.quote: The first one that the House will be interested in is that it enables the framework for digital driver licences to be introduced in New Zealand. Now, to be clear, the bill does not establish digital driver licences; it creates the framework for the ministry and officials to then go away and do the consultative work that we need to undertake.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tangi Utikere (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: We do support this bill as a form of technical but useful improvements to modernise our transportation system but, also, to look at reducing inefficiencies where that is able to be the case. While this is a bill that does tidy up some of those technical issues, in itself I don't think it will be as transformative as perhaps some would like.

conclusion: The Government advanced its core water and infrastructure agenda, facing fierce accusations that its reforms will deepen the financial pressures facing Kiwi households.
